displayed_text: Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA. Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s been tried; even the addition of chemotherapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yet it prolongs the recurrence, but it still doesn’t prevent the recurrence or prevent it recurring. Healthcare Professional: But then there’s therapies that happen. Doctor: Right. That’s one of the last options Healthcare Professional: Yeah, yeah, there are other therapies for when that happens. Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier.

Family Member: Good to see you. Other than that, Doctor: Yeah. I think she’s got a questionnaire or two for you. Okay. I’ll let A_ know. Patient: Now, you’re gonna, now they’re gonna check the pharmacy and let me know? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I have to – I give it to our pharmacist, and then she’ll start processing it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’ll take a day or two. Family Member: Alright. Thank you again.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right.

Patient: There’s uh, okay, is there any other; that was a surprise that it was larger, or that it was even there…there was a marker. Doctor: I know, yeah, the measurement totally did not indicate that. Patient: And why- Doctor: That was a shock. No, I agree with you. Patient: and that’s why – I don’t – that’s what I was trying to get at. It wasn’t there. Doctor: Yes, the reading was completely different from what actually was; you know that’s the problem, that the person reading is not the one doing the CRYO, in this case. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. So he’s the only one who would read them (papers shuffling) Patient: To see what happens, what’s going on. Doctor: Yeah, because the report - Healthcare Professional: It could switch; the report doesn’t say it helped. It didn’t say it was Doctor: No, I agree. Family Member: And to report that you got back.

Patient: In your, do you know what’s happening, I’m sure you do. Doctor: Yes. Patient: What’s happening now that I need more, sorry I don’t know why this happened but… Doctor: You got excited. Patient: Yeah (Laughing and all speaking at once.) Family Member: Take two. Patient: I’m just different, it happens here. Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill.

Family Member: They have different skin. Doctor: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Yeah, that part of it is funny because --- Alright, April seventeenth, the big day, we’ll get your PSA test. Are you, where do you do your PSA test? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Right here? Family Member: Uh. Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early?

Patient: …not that I know of. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And then that’s the lung doctor to look up these nodules in your lungs and that’s Dr. S___. And then when you come back it will be March eighth which is time for you next Lupron shot. And we’ll get bloodwork then too to make sure that you’re not rising on that number. Patient: Okay so now I just got to get an appointment today for these? Doctor: Yep when you walk out to where you checked in. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: They’re gonna review the schedule and then tell you when they’re available. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Nice to see you. Stay out of trouble will ya? Patient: I’ll try to. Patient: The best I can. The best I can. Doctor: Oh the best you can. I gotcha. Thanks again for waiting.

Patient: No. Doctor: No. Patient: Did you, did you see that Harvard study? Family Member: Okay Patient: I know, I know you are busy, but there was a Harvard study done by the African American study department. I forget his name, C__ something, and they, they took eight very, very prominent African American’s, Oprah, uh, uh, uh who’s the great arranger? Anyway. Ada, Quincy Jones. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, I, I say plan for three hours, but you know, if we do the Tuesday visit and clear you, then your other visits it can be the shorter end of things because they know you, they expected you, they’ve cleared you. Patient: Yeah, we’ll get into the pattern and we’ll just - Okay. Doctor: But, we’re not using, uh, uh a port. You know, we’re just going to use your regular vein. So, that would be something else that if your veins are too tough to get, uh, something like that. Patient: I’ll tell you that the phlebotomist that did it today was probably the least painful stick I’ve ever had. Doctor: Do you have any other questions?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s awesome. That’s really great. Cool. All right. What else? Patient: That’s about it, really, I mean. Doctor: Okay. Well, if you have more questions, I’m here. Patient: They’ll come up I’m sure. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Most of stuff I had looked up, and so it’s okay now. Now, does this drug actually kill the cancer? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It does? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So it’s almost like a chemotherapy? Doctor: Well, it’s like a super hormone. That’s really what it is. It sits in the hormone pathway, so, it’ll kill it like that. Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put it in there. Patient: You can see the real thing if you’d like. It’s right there. (Laughs) Doctor: And, how are you doin’ with just the bowels, to start with? Still everything okay? Patient: Uh. With my bowels? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Actually, better. Doctor: Better? Okay. Patient: Since the radiation. Doctor: Okay. So, once a day, twice a day? How often do you --- Patient: Well, somedays a couple of times a day. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Maybe three times.

Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum.
